column1: Will California voters approve Proposition 16 (Repeal Proposition 209 Affirmative Action Amendment)?
column6: ['Society', 'US Politics', 'Elections and Referenda']
CA has a strong support for minority groups. Woke culture.
This survey puts Prop 16 ahead 53% to 47%. Now I don't know what to think.
This survey puts Prop 16 ahead 53% to 47%. Now I don't know what to think.
https://www.sfgate.com/politics/article/Poll-California-Prop-16-15-21-22-Uber-rent-control-15675508.php
Paradigm shift. Rowing faster in the opposite direction.

Update my forecast based on more detailed polling data [1]. While the yes-no are 31 and 47%, there is a large number of undecided (22%). More interesting (and revealing) information is that while the moderates and conservatives are overwhelmingly against this proposition, only 46% of the liberals (and also 46% for the Democrats) are for it. So it appears that affirmative is not as favored by the liberals as commonly believed.
PUFF.....
https://www.ppic.org/wp-content/uploads/ppic-statewide-survey-californians-and-their-government-october-2020.pdf
This does not as likley to pass as it once did.

Polls show only 31% for Proposition 16, and 47% against [1]. That means more voters are in favor of banning affirmative action as stated in Proposition 209. Proposition 209 was passed with 55%. Despite California is a very liberal state and affirmative action is one of the pet project of the liberals, the banning of affirmative action appears to be still in favor by the current voters.

Polling indicates the Proposition will not pass, but the campaign supporting the proposition has a lot more funding, and it is likely that undecideds will swing towards voting 'Yes' - in the majority of propositions in California the 'Yes' side wins. Endorsements for the 'Yes' side are a lot stronger, leading Democrats including Joe Biden's running mate Kamala Harris. That being said, the 'Yes' side has a long distance to catch up - ballotpedia has them down by 10 points and even if the undecideds swing 2/3 towards 'Yes', they would still be losing by 52/48. It may be a close vote but in my view the most likely outcome is still a 'No' vote.
I wish I were wrong.
Heading toward the crowd on this one. Poorly worded Preposition in an election overshadowed by other chioces.

California voting demographics are represented at the following link: https://www.ppic.org/publication/californias-likely-voters/

Originally read this and thought it strange that everyone was so in favor of discrimination, but further research shows that, in actuality, this is phrased very much from the viewpoint of affirmative action and diversity initiatives, which makes much more sense. Current political climate supports such a change, especially in a state like CA, and the wording on the ballot is compelling to say the least (i.e. calling it "Allow Diversity as a Factor in Public Employment, Education, and Contracting Decisions. Legislative Constitutional Amendment"). I mean, what honest Californian would vote against diversity? I think it will pass, though I am a little worried how it may be used in future legislation and rulings given it says nothing about the negative discrimination that could occur. Could this allow someone to be fired or not hired based on race or sexual orientation or some other characteristic? If anyone knows I'd love to hear it.
The climate is ripe for this to pass with overwhelming support.
Should put more effort into this one

Being the "inside view" as a Californian and one of those people who digs into propositions, this rings of Props that pass. Big name backing, lots of funding. Just ask yourself how SF, LA and San Diego will vote and that is your answer. The only doubt comes in the verbiage, which is intentionally confusing.

Really recommend looking at @benjuliano1 for insight as to the base rate for this question. 55% implied base rate is well above the crowd forecast right now (28%) and that surprises me, for a variety of reasons.

Our base rate should be 55 percent. That’s the percentage of ballot measures that California voters have approved over the past ten years. Californians have a mixed record with affirmative action but not one that qualifies as establishing any significant history. Voters in the state have only considered such questions twice in 1996 and 2003 respectively. [1][2]

I'll have to watch this one, I'm afraid. Referenda are a terrible idea, and California is California. The combination begs for, and has often resulted in, incoherent policymaking, frequently inadvertent. This will cut cruelly into my nap time.
This repeal will likely confuse a lot of people, but I am hoping it fails with my forecast. PS the title incorrectly cites Prop 205, it should read Prop 209.
the woke crusade will continue
